**Course Description:**

This course aims to lead students to engage in studies of the intersections among music, society, and culture. Specifically, in this semester this course will guide students to think about the roles that music plays in the construction and continuation of societies, cultures, and the environment, especially at a time when we are facing various kinds of crises of the Anthropocene. Through interacting with instructors and guest speakers’ lectures and participating in in-course presentation and discussion sessions, as well as completing mid-term presentation and individual term paper, students will learn how people around the world promote cultural diversity, social justice, and environmental sustainability through musical practices. In addition, the reading materials and weekly discussions will help students develop their skills of critical thinking, public presentation, and academic writing in English.

**Course Grading:**

This course adopts the following criteria to evaluate students’ performance:

1.  In-class presentations (ICP) (2 times; 10% each): 20%
2.  In-class responses to Discussion Sessions (DS) (15 times; 3% each): 45%
3.  Attendance in and responses to the three Guest Lectures (GL): (3 times; 5% each): 15%
4.  Midterm presentation (group): 10%
5.  Final paper (individual): 10%
6.  Bonus: Students who actively respond to classroom activities may get bonus points (up to 5 points) for their participation.

**NTNU Grade Scale and Conversion Chart:** http://iweb.ntnu.edu.tw/aa/gpaweb/pic/FAQ\_English%20version.pdf

**Plagiarism**:

Students are to abide by and subject to all university policies in relation to academic integrity. Following academic ethics, especially appropriate citation, is a must. Students are encouraged to consult the instructor regarding appropriate citation and circumstances that may constitute academic dishonesty. Plagiarism and other forms of academic misconduct will not be tolerated in any way. Any work that is found to be involved with such misconduct will receive a failing grading and the incident will be handled according to the policies of the university.

Form of Final Paper: Individual Paper

            What: Academic Essay on Music, Society and Culture

How: Choose one chapter from _Resounding Taiwan: Musical Reverberations Across a Vibrant Island_ (Guy 2021), and write a 2000-word academic essay in relation to the chapter. Make sure you (1) summarize the chapter, (2) develop an argument with concrete evidence, (3) respond to the literature introduced in this class, and (4) follow the Turabian citation style (https://www.chicagomanualofstyle.org/turabian/turabian-notes-and-bibliography-citation-quick-guide.html) to present notes and bibliography.

**Final paper due at 18:00, Jan. 25, 2022**
